questions.question_text: Which component of the AWS global infrastructure provides low-latency access to content in multiple geographic areas by storing copies of data close to end users?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
D. Edge locations

AWS Edge locations are part of the AWS global infrastructure that provide low-latency access to content by storing copies of data close to end users. Edge locations are strategically placed in multiple geographic areas around the world and are optimized to deliver content quickly and efficiently to end users. They are used by services such as Amazon CloudFront and Amazon Route 53 to cache and serve content, such as images, videos, and web pages, to users with minimal latency. Edge locations work in conjunction with AWS Regions and Availability Zones to provide a highly available and globally distributed infrastructure.

Selected Answer: D
D. Edge locations

"Edge locations are AWS data centers designed to deliver services with the lowest latency possible. Amazon has dozens of these data centers spread across the world. They’re closer to users than Regions or Availability Zones, often in major cities, so responses can be fast and snappy. " 

https://www.lastweekinaws.com/blog/what-is-an-edge-location-in-aws-a-simple-explanation/#:~:text=Edge%20locations%20are%20AWS%20data,can%20be%20fast%20and%20snappy.
"Content" seems to be the keyword. It implies the question is about the CDN, and thus "edge locations" are relevant.

Selected Answer: D
D is the answer.

Selected Answer: C
C. Amazon RDS

"Amazon RDS gives you access to the capabilities of a familiar MySQL, MariaDB, Oracle, SQL Server, or PostgreSQL database. This means that the code, applications, and tools you already use today with your existing databases should work seamlessly with Amazon RDS. "

https://aws.amazon.com/rds/faqs/

Selected Answer: C
C is the answer.

Selected Answer: C
C is correct.

questions.question_text:
A company wants to migrate its Microsoft SQL Server database management system from on premises to the AWS Cloud.

Which AWS service should the company use to reduce management overhead for this environment?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
C. Amazon DynamoDB

"Amazon DynamoDB is a fully managed, serverless, key-value NoSQL database designed to run high-performance applications at any scale. DynamoDB offers built-in security, continuous backups, automated multi-Region replication, in-memory caching, and data import and export tools."
https://aws.amazon.com/dynamodb/

Selected Answer: C
C is the answer.

Selected Answer: C
C is correct.

choices.B: Microsoft SQL Server on Amazon EC2

questions.question_text:
A cloud practitioner needs to design a NoSQL database that is highly scalable, is durable, and requires minimal maintenance.

Which AWS service meets these requirements?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BE
B & E are correct.

Selected Answer: BE
B. Regions consist of multiple Availability Zones.
E. Regions are located around the world.

Selected Answer: BE
BE is the answer.

questions.question_text: Which of the following are characteristics of AWS Regions and Availability Zones? (Choose two.)

choices.C: An Availability Zone contains several Regions.
choices.D: Regions are within 100 km (60 miles) of each other.
choices.A: Regions bring AWS services to on-premises facilities.
choices.B: Regions consist of multiple Availability Zones.
choices.E: Regions are located around the world.

questions.question_text:
A company moves a workload to AWS to run on Amazon EC2 instances. The company needs to run the workload in the most cost-effective way.

What can the company do to meet this requirement?

choices.C: Use AWS CloudFormation to deploy the infrastructure.
choices.A: Use AWS Key Management Service (AWS KMS).
choices.B: Use multiple AWS accounts and consolidated billing.
choices.D: Rightsize all the EC2 instances that are used in the deployment.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
D is correct.

Selected Answer: D
D. Rightsize all the EC2 instances that are used in the deployment.

"Right sizing is the most effective way to control cloud costs. It involves continually analyzing instance performance and usage needs and patterns—and then turning off idle instances and right sizing instances that are either overprovisioned or poorly matched to the workload. Because your resource needs are always changing, right sizing must become an ongoing process to continually achieve cost optimization. "

https://aws.amazon.com/aws-cost-management/aws-cost-optimization/right-sizing/

Selected Answer: D
D is the answer.
